translated: The Pāṭimokkha of the Theravāda tradition
The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on relinquishment
The sub-chapter on robes
The second training rule on storing

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

original: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro puriso aññataraṁ purisaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena aññataraḥ purisaḥ aññataram purisam etat avoca
translated: On one occasion a man said to another,
“I’ll give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”
The other said,

original: “ahampi ayyaṁ upanandaṁ cīvarena acchādessāmī”ti.🔽Assosi kho aññataro piṇḍacāriko bhikkhu tesaṁ purisānaṁ imaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ.
analyzed: aham pi ayyam upanandam cīvarena acchādessāmi iti  assosi kho aññataraḥ piṇḍacārikaḥ bhikkhu tesam purisānam imam kathā sallāpa
translated: “I’ll also give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”🔽A monk who was wandering for alms heard that conversation.

original: Atha kho so bhikkhu yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ upanandaṁ sakyaputtaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: atha kho saḥ bhikkhu yena āyasmā upanandaḥ sakya putto tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam upanandam sakya puttam etat avoca
translated: He then went to Upananda and said,

analyzed: mahā puññaḥ asi tvaḥ āvuso upananda
translated: “You have great merit, Venerable Upananda.

original: Amukasmiṁ okāse aññataro puriso aññataraṁ purisaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: amukasmin okāse aññataraḥ puriso aññataram purisam etat avoca
translated: In such-and-such a place a man said to another,
‘I’ll give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.’
The other said,

analyzed: aham pi ayyam upanandam cīvarena acchādessāmi iti
translated: ‘I’ll give you robe-cloth.’”

analyzed: atthi āvuso mam te upaṭṭhākā ti
translated: “I have attendants.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto yena te purisā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te purise etadavoca—
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai upanandaḥ sakya puttaḥ yena te purisā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā te purise etat avoca
translated: Upananda then went to those men and said,

original: “saccaṁ kira maṁ tumhe, āvuso, cīvarehi acchādetukāmātthā”ti?
analyzed: saccam kira mama tumhe āvuso cīvarehi acchādetu kāmā āttha ati
translated: “Is it true that you want to give me robe-cloth?”
“It’s true.”
“It’s not right that you should give me robe-cloth.”🔽“If you want to give me robe-cloth,

original: “Sace kho maṁ tumhe, āvuso, cīvarehi acchādetukāmāttha, evarūpena cīvarena acchādetha,
analyzed: sace kho mama tumhe āvuso cīvarehi acchādetu kāmāḥ āttha evarūpena cīvarena acchādetha
translated: then give me this kind of robe-cloth.

original: kyāhaṁ tehi acchannopi karissāmi, yānāhaṁ na paribhuñjissāmī”ti.
analyzed: kyā aham tehi a channaḥ api karissāmi yānā aham na paribhuñjissāmi iti
translated: What can I do with robe-cloth that I won’t use?”

original: Atha kho te purisā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
analyzed: atha kho te purisāḥ ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti
translated: Those men complained and criticized him,

analyzed: mahicchāḥ ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyāḥ a santuṭṭhā
translated: “These Sakyan monastics are greedy. They’re not content with the robe-cloth they already have.
It’s not easy to give them robe-cloth.

original: Kathañhi nāma ayyo upanando amhehi pubbe appavārito upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjissatī”ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma ayyaḥ upanandaḥ amhehi pubbe a pavāritaḥ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjissati iti
translated: How could Venerable Upananda come to us and ask for a choice of robe-cloth without first being invited to do so?”

original: Assosuṁ kho bhikkhū tesaṁ purisānaṁ ujjhāyantānaṁ khiyyantānaṁ vipācentānaṁ.
analyzed: assosum kho bhikkhū tesam purisānam ujjhāyantānam khiyyantānam vipācentāna
translated: The monks heard the complaints of those men,

original: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
analyzed: ye te bhikkhū appicchā pe te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti
translated: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

original: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā upanando sakyaputto pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjissatī”ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma āyasman upanandaḥ sakya putto pubbe appavāritaḥ gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjissati iti
translated: “How could Venerable Upananda go to the householders and choose cloth without first being invited?”

original: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṁ upanandaṁ sakyaputtaṁ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ …pe…
analyzed: atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantam upanandam sakya puttam aneka pariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavataḥ etam attham ārocesuṃ pe
translated: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:

original: “saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, upananda, pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjasī”ti?
analyzed: saccam kira tvam upananda pubbe a pavāritaḥ gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjasi iti
translated: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
“It’s true, Sir.”
“Are they your relatives or not?”
“They’re not, Sir.”

original: “Aññātako, moghapurisa, aññātakānaṁ na jānāti patirūpaṁ vā appatirūpaṁ vā santaṁ vā asantaṁ vā.
analyzed: aññātakaḥ mogha purisa aññātakānam na jānāti patirūpam vā appatirūpam vā santam vā asantam vā
translated: “Foolish man, a relative knows what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with a relative.

original: Tattha nāma tvaṁ, moghapurisa, pubbe appavārito aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjissasi.
analyzed: tattha nāma tva mogha purisa pubbe a pavāritaḥ aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjissasi
translated: How could you, with no consultation beforehand, approach unrelated male and female householders and make demands about robe-cloth?

analyzed: neta moghapurisa appasannānam vā pasādāya pe
translated: This neither inspires faith in the faithless …” …

original: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ uddiseyyātha—
analyzed: evam ca pana bhikkhave imam sikkhāpadam uddiseyyātha
translated: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

original: “Bhikkhuṁ paneva uddissa ubhinnaṁ aññātakānaṁ gahapatīnaṁ vā gahapatānīnaṁ vā paccekacīvaracetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti—
analyzed: bhikkhum pana eva uddissa ubhinnam aññātakānam gahapatīnam vā gahapatānīnam vā pacceka cīvara cetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti
translated: ‘If a monk, with no consultation beforehand, approaches unrelated male and female householders and makes demands about robe-cloth, saying,

original: ‘imehi mayaṁ paccekacīvaracetāpannehi paccekacīvarāni cetāpetvā itthannāmaṁ bhikkhuṁ cīvarehi acchādessāmā’ti;
analyzed: imehi mayam pacceka cīvara cetāpannehi pacceka cīvarāni cetāpetvā itthannāmam bhikkhum cīvarehi acchādessāma ati
translated: “With these pieces of cloth, sirs, please buy such-and-such a robe-cloth and give it to monk so-and-so,”

original: tatra ce so bhikkhu pubbe appavārito upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjeyya—
analyzed: tatra ce saḥ bhikkhu pubbe a pavāritaḥ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjeyya
translated: and if that monk, before being invited, then specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,

original: ‘sādhu vata maṁ āyasmanto imehi paccekacīvaracetāpannehi evarūpaṁ vā evarūpaṁ vā cīvaraṁ cetāpetvā acchādetha, ubhova santā ekenā’ti,
analyzed: sādhu vata mama āyasmantaḥ imehi pacceka cīvara cetāpannehi evarūpam vā evarūpam vā cīvaram cetāpetvā acchādetha ubho uva santau ekena ati
translated: “It would be good if you bought such-and-such a robe-cloth and gave it to me,”
because of a desire for what is lovely, it is to be relinquished and confessed.”
If he is told to:

original: bhikkhussatthāya, bhikkhuṁ ārammaṇaṁ karitvā, bhikkhuṁ acchādetukāmā.
analyzed: bhikkhuḥ satthāya bhikkhum ārammaṇam karitvā bhikkhum a chādetu kāmā
translated: if it is for the sake of a monk, if it is for the sake of a monk that they are stored, if it is for the sake of a monk that they are bought,
Both:
two.
Unrelated:

original: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddhā.
analyzed: mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ vā yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā a sambaddhā
translated: on the mother’s or father’s side, back to the seventh generation, they are not related.
A householder:
any man who lives at home.
A householder’s wife:
any woman who lives at home.
Cloth:

original: hiraññā vā suvaṇṇā vā muttā vā maṇī vā pavāḷā vā phalikā vā paṭakā vā suttā vā kappāsā vā.
analyzed: hiraññā vā suvaṇṇā vā muttāḥ vā maṇī vā pavāḷāḥ vā phalikāḥ vā paṭakāḥ vā suttāḥ vā kappāsāḥ vā
translated: gold, silver, pearls, gems, corals, crystals, cloth, cotton, or yarn.
These individual pieces of cloth:
if they are available.
After having them bought:
after having them exchanged.🔽We will give:
we will give to him.
If that monk:

original: yaṁ bhikkhuṁ uddissa cīvaracetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti so bhikkhu.
analyzed: yam bhikkhum uddissa cīvara cetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti saḥ bhikkhu
translated: the monk for whom the cloth has been bought.
If he has not first been asked:

original: pubbe avutto hoti— “kīdisena te, bhante, cīvarena attho, kīdisaṁ te cīvaraṁ cetāpemā”ti.
analyzed: pubbe a vuttaḥ hoti kīdisena te bhante cīvarena atthaḥ kīdisam te cīvaram cetāpema ati
translated: He has not said, “Venerables, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth should I buy?”
Approaches:
having gone to the house, having approached anywhere.
Becomes intent on robe-cloth:

original: āyataṁ vā hotu vitthataṁ vā appitaṁ vā saṇhaṁ vā.
analyzed: āyatam vā hotu vitthatam vā appitam vā saṇham vā
translated: it should be long or wide or thin or thick.
These kinds of buying robe-cloth:

analyzed: paccupaṭṭhitehi  evarūpam vai evarūpam vā ati
translated: when they are available.🔽Such and such:

original: āyataṁ vā vitthataṁ vā appitaṁ vā saṇhaṁ vā.
analyzed: āyatam vā vitthatam vā appitam vā saṇham vā
translated: long or wide or thin or thick.
Having bought:
having exchanged.
Should give:

analyzed: dajjetha  ubhau uva santau ekena ati
translated: should give to him.🔽Both of them together:
both of them together.
Out of a desire to do what is agreeable:

original: sādhatthiko mahagghatthiko.🔽Tassa vacanena āyataṁ vā vitthataṁ vā appitaṁ vā saṇhaṁ vā cetāpenti, payoge dukkaṭaṁ.
analyzed: sādhatthikaḥ mahagghatthikaḥ  tassa vacanena āyatam vā vitthatam vā appitam vā saṇham vā cetāpenti payoge dukkaṭa
translated: desiring what is good, desiring what is expensive.
If, because of his statement, they buy long, wide, thin, or thick robe-cloth, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

original: Nissajjitabbaṁ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
analyzed: nissajjitabbam saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā
translated: When it is obtained, it is to be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
And it should be relinquished like this.
And it should be relinquished like this. …

original: “idaṁ me, bhante, cīvaraṁ pubbe appavārito aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpannaṁ nissaggiyaṁ.
analyzed: idam me bhante cīvaram pubbe a pavāritaḥ aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpannam nissaggiya
translated: … ‘Venerables, this robe, which I got by bartering for robe-cloth without first being invited to do so, is to be relinquished.

analyzed: imā aham saṅghassa nissajjāmi iti pe  dadeyyā ati pe
translated: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …🔽‘Give it to a sangha, a group, or an individual.’ …
‘Give it to a sangha, a group, or an individual.’ …

original: āyasmato dammīti.🔽Aññātake aññātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.🔽Aññātake vematiko pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ dammi iti  aññātake aññātaka saññī pubbe a pavāritaḥ gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjati nissaggiyam pācittiya  aññātake vematikaḥ pubbe a pavāritaḥ gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjati nissaggiyam pācittiya
translated: ‘I give it to you.’”🔽If the householders are unrelated, and the monk perceives them as such, and he gets them to barter for robe-cloth without first being invited to do so, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.🔽If the householders are unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he gets them to barter for robe-cloth without first being invited to do so, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

original: Aññātake ñātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.🔽Ñātake aññātakasaññī, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: aññātake ñātaka saññī pubbe a pavāritaḥ gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappam āpajjati nissaggiyam pācittiya  ñātake aññātaka saññī āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If the householders are unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he gets them to barter for robe-cloth without first being invited to do so, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.🔽If the householders are related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If the householders are related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If the householders are related, and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
There is no offense if he gets them to barter for robe-cloth after first being invited to do so;
when it is for a relative;🔽when it is for someone who has given prior notice;
when it is for someone else;

analyzed: attanaḥ dhanena  mahaggham cetā apetu kāmānam appaggham cetā apeti
translated: when it is with one’s own money;🔽when the donor wants to give something expensive, but the recipient gives something cheap instead;
when the recipient is insane;
when the recipient is the first offender.
The second training rule on what is set aside, the ninth, is finished.
